text: great thanks for the introduction Michael so as Michael said I'm a new assistant professor in the mechanical
engineering design group and teaching classes for the product design program and also around kind of the intersection
between HCI and you know design and the physical world so anyway today I'm going
to talk a little bit about some of the work that I was doing at the MIT Media Lab during my PhD and postdoc and then
also briefly talk about some directions of the things that are going on at my lab here which were tentatively calling
the physical inner interaction group but we'll see anyway so before I get started
talking about sort of what I've been working on I think you know looking back to sort of the rich history of tools and
thinking about where tools come from is something that I think is really central to our role as designers of of objects
and of interfaces and so these are hand axes that are that our ancestors made you know many many years ago and these
were made not only to fit you know the their hands but also to fit the task at
hand and you know we've evolved with tools and and tools have evolved with us
and so over time you know all of these tools have become increasingly specialized and designers of these tools
have gotten really good at matching their physical form to both how they want to manipulate the world as well as
how you want to hold them and so the physical form matches the functionality
and can harness the richness and dexterity of our hand but again tools
not only allow us to manipulate the world tools can also be used to build other tools that can help us think about
problems and think about space and think about interacting with other people but
as tools have become more complex we've you know designed really great ways to
allow for you know the manipulation of different parameters while you're attending to different tasks and so
these physical affordances the designers have gotten very good at at trading really allow us to to do many different
things Wow we're not necessarily focusing on them and the best interfaces are really those
that sort of blend into the background or sort of become part of the task itself however I think the computer has
really changed the way that we interact and also change the way that we think about tools pretty much you know most
tools that we use on a daily basis now are either on a computer or used computers as part of the process and the
thing that's really changed about this is that computation is dynamic and so as such it can do millions of different
things so you know your standard computer can have you know the millions of different applications that can run
on it but most computing systems really have the same static physical
affordances for all these different applications so you're using the keyboard in the mouse or multi touch
interaction for both you know composing an email as you would be for playing a
musical instrument or playing a game or browsing a large data set or modeling
something on a computer aided design tool and so I think that this is fundamentally a problem and so my belief
is that we need computers that can physically adapt to us to match their form to this dynamic computation as well
and that's what I've been working on at the MIT Media Lab and now I hope to be doing the same thing at Stanford and so
at MIT together with Daniel light finger and my former advisor Hiroshi issue we
build this system in form that allows you to take digital information and make it now physical so you can interact with
it directly and you can use that to visualize 3d information that you can touch and feel in different ways so for
example you can understand the slope and curves of a math equation as opposed to
just seeing it or users can interact directly through touch and gesture to to
sculpt digital clay and so you can use your hands in different ways that you
wouldn't be able to with a traditional multi-touch or mouse and keyboard interface but in addition physical
interface elements can appear and disappear on demand and the idea is that
for all these different applications the physical form can reflect these these things is there a way for me to

tangible interfaces and a lot of these really stem from learnings about
cognitive science and how we think about problems and how we can offload those into the physical world and so one of
those notions is this notion of epistemic action so being able to externalize our thoughts into the
physical world and so there's been this rich history of tangibles and then more
recently you know in addition to the haptic interfaces that have been going on for a long time there's been working
sort of actuated tangible interfaces which can use you know in the case of Pico which was from the tangible media
grip uses magnets to move around these physical objects or or for example
Fabian hemert shape-changing mobile device uses servo motors to give you feedback on these things however most of
these examples can sort of only change between a few different states or are limited to sort of 2d interaction and so
another direction that's been really exciting that we've built on a lot is this notion of shape displays where as opposed to
sort of a traditional haptic interface where you might have you know something
like the haptic phantom where you have a tethered device that's giving you force
feedback here the idea is to create a tactile display that you can touch and feel with your hands but you can also
see it and so that means that it can allow for multiple users to interact with it and other things like that so
project felix is one of the the first ones of these but there's been a number of others such as Ivan puppy revs lumen
and then a lot of the work from the media lab however a lot of these systems
have really focused on only thinking about how do you display 3d information and so really the focus of our work has
been to think not only about the content but also how do you create new types of user interfaces and user interface
paradigms for these new types of systems and so one of these things sort of is the central concept to to a lot of
things that I've been working on is this notion of dynamic physical affordances that we want to have physical
affordances that can allow the user to both understand how they can use this system but they need to adapt to these
different applications and so some examples of you know what these could be
on the inform shape display because sort of this kind of low resolution prototyping platform that we've built
are you know you can render sort of buttons or sliders on demand and then
they can become you know they can change their position and resize and they can
be touch sensitive as well or they can
you know morph between input dimensions so you can have a button that can then become sort of this touch selector and
so it gives you this continuity between them or they can also be context-aware
so you can have them resize based on how close you are there's this target expansion that's been done in you know
in mouse and keyboard interfaces but now we can do these types of things in the physical world and so these parameters
of these dynamic affordances we can really manipulate a number of different things so we can change their
shape their size their position and orientation their color their visibility
as well as the way that they feel so their haptic feedback so we can change the stiffness as you're as you're
touching it and I think what's interesting about this is that shape displays really allow us to have a much
when we're coming from thinking about graphical user interfaces they really
allow us to have a better way to map these traditional interfaces into now 3d interaction that can become physical and
material so for example the software stack that we built is very similar to how you would program a traditional
graphical user interface but we can also do things like appropriate existing
objects as interface elements and use the shape display to move them so for example we can have a scroll bar where
or a play bar where the play bar is actually moving the sphere and then you
can interact with it as well and so the idea is not only to use the shape display to display these dynamic
affordances directly but we can also use appropriate passive objects as well and so that means that we can do things like
move objects around the table so for example if someone receives a phone call but they're not looking at it then you
could actually sort of you know move move the phone move the phone to them so
you know this is kind of like a little fun example and so all of this is built
on this inform platform that Daniel Lightning der and I built and so it's kind of this brute force approach to how
you might build one of these systems so it uses 900 linear actuators and then these mechanical linkages to get a
higher or higher resolution in a smaller footprint a larger footprint at the
bottom but you know this isn't how we envision these being built in in the
long-term really we're interested in using these two prototype new types of interactions and applications so this is

and so yeah as I mentioned there's 900 actuators and we ended up you these Alps motorized slide
potentiometers for the actuators because they're inexpensive but you can also
back drive them and they're very robust the other thing that I think is one interesting aspect of the in-form system
first prior shape displays is that it's it's quite fast and I think that that speed really allowed it to have this
interactive quality that we were going for so that was something that I think a lot of the other shape displays have
kind of slower types of actuation like shape memory alloy or pneumatic systems
but here we really wanted to have something that was fast and so we went with these yeah in terms of the speed or
so I think definitely we wanted it to be interactive but we've spent a lot of
time thinking about like why was this why did this work so much better or was
more compelling than other shape displays that for example lumen which is Ivan popular Oh system I think is really

pixels but it has about the same resolution but it is much slower and so I think that we did get a little lucky
that there was this nice sweet spot of sort of speed cost and the number of
actuators that we used but I think it's also interesting so previously Daniel had built a lower resolution shape
display and that really didn't allow us to display very many things and so this
kind of stepped to the next resolution it wasn't an order of magnitude but somewhere close to that I think really
got you a lot and so I think similarly you'd find that if you jumped down another step you you would probably find
even more interesting applications that we can't really do with this just because of the the scale of the pixels
so but yeah in terms of shape displays I think there is this trade-off between sort of the number of actuators that
you're using the cost and then the speed or force and so it's kind of this interesting space to work in so then we
develop these custom motor drivers and it's all connected this RS 45 bus and then we can update it
at 60 frames per second although you know with the motor speed as I mentioned before it kind of changes things and
then we have a depth sensing camera from above to track input and then we can
also sense the position of the pins for interaction so after building the system
one thing that we thought a really interesting application for this was collaborative design and collaboration
across distances and so one because when we're interacting in person we use you
know physical objects we sketch on paper and we aren't just looking at someone's face so we're trying to think about how
we could have a richer sense of collaboration at a distance and one of the advantages of these shape displays
is that you can do something across a distance like that so we work Daniel and
I work together on this notion of physical telepresence so how could we create this shape display system that
could both not only display content and user interface but should also display a
remote person as well and so as I mentioned you know when we're collaborating in person especially
around design tasks we have physical artifacts and space that we really use
as part of this process and I think that you know there are you know in this
space you know people objects and tools and then the environment as well and and
when we think about what we imagine you know remote collaboration to be like you know maybe we think more about this sort
of skype based windowing metaphor and obviously there's been a lot of work in

there but we're still sort of limited to this screen based interaction and so the
question is how can we use these shape displays to now enable this type of rich
collaboration that we have in person but at a distance and so we think that
there's sort of four aspects to this approach that are really important so one is physical embodiment so how can we
capture and remotely render a person's body parts and gesture is using this system so so
here you can see that we use the shape display to represent a remote users hands second is interaction with

across distances then thirdly we want to talk about how we can go beyond this
one-to-one mapping of a representation of a person to expand their capabilities
and so this notion of you know beyond being there physically how can you actually make the person who's remote

we manipulate shared content by deforming it directly and so here you can think about having two linked 3d
